courses.subject: URBD
courses.title: Environmental & Urban Economics
courses.description: This course will study urban economic issues associated with environmental and social issues within urban regions. The course will study this topic from an interdisciplinary perspective. A range of topics in urban economics will be discussed including planning policies related to urban environment, migration, and transportation, as well as, zoning and livability issues, and potentials for more sustainable, just and livable cities. Students will become familiar with contemporary urban economic research and online sources of economic data. The course will prepare students to develop criteria for value judgments about the complex social, economic and environmental impact of urban design and planning.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of MSc in Urban Design and MSc in Advanced Environmental Planning Technologies.
courses.learning_outcomes:
On successful completion of this unit, students will be able to:
1. Demonstrate a basic understanding of the principles of macro and micro economic theory and the valuation of environmental resources.
2. Apply elementary methods of economic analysis to contemporary issues relating to the planning and management of built and natural environments.
courses.course_syllabus: This course studies urban economic issues associated with environmental and social issues within urban regions. The course will study this topic from an interdisciplinary perspective. A range of topics in urban economics will be discussed including planning policies related to urban environment, migration, and transportation, as well as, zoning and liability issues, and potentials for more sustainable, just and liveable cities. Students will become familiar with contemporary urban economic research and online sources of economic data. The course will prepare students to develop criteria for value judgments about the complex social, economic and environmental impact of urban design and planning.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course evaluations, feedback to essays, external examiner report .
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the recommended readings.

courses.subject: URBD
courses.title: Urban History & Theory

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G03

courses.description: This course examines the main ideas, histories and theories of the city through specific local and international examples from significant historical, political, geographical and environmental periods and aspects. Important themes and debates in urban design and planning will be critically explored to understand the relationship between the urban forms, the culture of cities and their sustainable development. In particular, the way urban forms have been used and reinterpreted, adapted and challenged by different social, economic and political contexts. Exemplary design projects and planning policies are investigated in view of their relationship to contexts and their impacts on communities and the environment.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of MSc in Urban Design and Master of Architecture;Mutually exclusive to ARCH5721
courses.learning_outcomes: This course will provide students with skills to understand complex forces that shape cities, and introduces critical methods and tools to describe and theorize the urban processes that influence the built environment. Using a themed approach and in-depth case studies, students will learn to articulate the relationship between visual and physical form of the urban environment and urban settings, processes and contexts in different perspectives, styles and methods of inquiry.
courses.course_syllabus: This course examines the main ideas, histories and theories of the city through specific local and international examples from significant historical, political, geographical and environmental periods and aspects. Important themes and debates in urban design and planning will be critically explored to understand the relationship between the urban forms, the culture of cities and their sustainable development. In particular, the way urban forms have been used and reinterpreted, adapted and challenged by different social, economic and political contexts. Exemplary design projects and planning policies are investigated in view of their relationship to contexts and their impacts on communities and the environment.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course evaluations, individual feedback on papers, external examiner report
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the recommended readings.
courses.recommended_readings:

Koolhaas, R. (1994) Delirious New York.

Miles, M. [et al.] (2000) The city cultures reader.
Mumford, L. (1989) The city in history.
Mumford, L. (1997) The culture of cities.
Parker, S (2004), Urban theory and the urban experience: encountering the city.
Robbins E. & El-Khoury, R. (eds) (2004) Shaping the city: studies in history, theory and urban design.

courses.subject: URBD
courses.title: Research Methods in Urban Design
courses.description: This course consolidates students understanding of academic inquiry and enables them to conduct a range of research methods relevant for the field of urban design. The first part of the course covers general aspects such as research ethics, scoping of research areas, conceptualizing research frameworks and identifying relevant research questions. The second part provides students with the relevant research methods and skills for urban design, such as conducting field studies, surveys and semi-structured interviews, as well as performing a range of qualitative and quantitative analyses. Throughout the course, students will learn how to relate their findings from their mixed-method studies to address complex urban issues. The course is coordinated with students’ work in the design studio and prepares them for their final thesis project. Assignments are organized according to sub-themes linked to the core issues of urban design.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc in Urban Design and Master of Architecture
courses.learning_outcomes: At the completion of this course, students will be able (1) to understand core aspects of academic research (including research ethics, development of research frameworks etc.), (2) to study and apply a range of research methods for the investigation of complex urban contexts and sites, (3) to collect and evaluate data sets from various sources, and (4) to integrate their findings into their urban design processes. Thus the course will prepare students for their final thesis project as well as foster their ability of life-long learning.
courses.course_syllabus: Please refer to to course outline.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course evaluations, individual feedback on papers, external examiner report
courses.required_readings:
Cuthbert, Alexander R. Understanding Cities: Method in Urban Design. Milton Park, Abingdon, Oxon; New York: Routledge, 2011.
Eco, Umberto (author), Francesco Erspamer (introduction). How to Write a Thesis. Cambridge, MA: MIT Press, 2015.
courses.recommended_readings:
Farrell, Peter. Writing a Built Environment Dissertation: Practical Guidance and Examples. Chichester, West Sussex; Ames, Iowa: Wiley-Blackwell, 2011.
Jong, Voordt, and Jong, Taeke M. De. Ways to Study and Research: Urban, Architectural and Technical Design. Delft: DUP Science, 2002.
Leavy, Patricia. Research Design: Quantitative, Qualitative, Mixed Methods, Arts-based, and Community-based Participatory Research Approaches. 2017.
Cosgrove, Denis E. Mappings. Critical Views. London: Reaktion Books, 1999.
Small, Mario Luis. "`How Many Cases Do I Need?': On Science and the Logic of Case Selection in Field-based Research." Ethnography 10, no. 1 (2009): 5-38.
Small, Mario Luis. "How to Conduct a Mixed Methods Study: Recent Trends in a Rapidly Growing Literature." Annual Review of Sociology 37 (2011): 57-86.

courses.subject: URBD
courses.title: Urban Design Studio I

meetings.instructor:
Ms. CHEUNG Tin Yan, 
Professor Jeroen Bastiaan VAN AMEIJDE

Ms. CHEUNG Tin Yan, 
Professor Jeroen Bastiaan VAN AMEIJDE

courses.description: UD Studio I will focus on existing urban districts in the Pearl River Delta region including Hong Kong and Macau and beyond. Students develop in groups and as individuals a design project exploring opportunities for neighborhoods and public spaces.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of MSc in Urban Design and Master of Architecture.
courses.learning_outcomes: Students begin to understand key urban issues, to come up with innovative and creative place making solutions to address some of the urban issues. Students develop capability to analyse urban forms and the forces resulting in the transformation of the urban fabric in existing areas and neighbourhoods. Students learn to facilitate participation of multiple stakeholders in a workshop setting and to help develop proposals and urban design strategies resuting design intervention at the local in community scale. Students gain experience working in groups and individually, to be better prepared for the real world, fostering critical thinking skills, about how to address community and environmental issues in a context sensitive and sustainable way.
courses.course_syllabus: UD Studio I focuses on existing urban districts in the Greater Bay Area including Hong Kong and Macau and beyond. Students develop in groups and as individuals a design project exploring opportunities for neighborhoods and public spaces.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Course Evaluation
Weekily feedback in desk critiques for indiviaual students and groups.
Sequence of reviews with invited critics from academia and practice.
External examiners after final review.

courses.description: Urban Design Studio II focuses on the creation of a new urban area. Students develop in groups and as individuals on a design project.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students of MSc in Urban Design and Master of Architecture.
Prerequiste: URBD5710 or ARCH5111
courses.learning_outcomes: 1) Development of advanced design skills in urban design; 2) Capability to analyse urban and land forms and their interrelation; 3) Development of design porposals based on an integration of knowledge of complex ecosystems; 4) Integration of different urban transport networks based on their capability to create a livable and sustainable environment; 5) Development of the ability to work in teams and with various professional consultants; 6) Fostering critical thinking.
courses.course_syllabus: Urban Design Studio II focuses on the creation of a new urban area. Students develop in groups and as individuals on a design project.
courses.feedback_evaluation: 1) Course evaluations; 2) weekily feedback in desk critiques for individual students and groups; 3) sequence of reviews with invited ciritics from academia and practice; and 4) external examiner reports

courses.subject: URBD
courses.title: Topical Studies in Urban Design 1 - Urban Processes

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G01

courses.description: The course focuses on the urban processes involved in the development and redevelopment of cities. Through lectures and seminars key issues, problems and challenges associated with urbanization and current trends within regional and international context are discussed. The plan making process in Hong Kong including public engagement within the city and the wider PRD context is introduced. Current trends in urban transformation processes in other parts of the world are looked at through regional and international case studies.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of MArch, MSc in Urban Design and MSSc in Housing Studies
courses.learning_outcomes: Students deepen their apprecaition for the urban processes involved in the development and redevelopment of cities and begin to understand the complex nature of problems and challenges associated with city development and urbanization processes. Students explore critical issues related to urban core developments, urban renewal of older urban districts, urban expansion through reclamation and new town development. Students learn to differentiate between top down and bottom up approaches and the importance of involving the public in the planning and the decision making process to create a sense of ownership of the city.
courses.course_syllabus: The course focuses on the urban processes involved in the development and redevelopment of cities. Through lectures and seminars key issues, problems and challenges associated with urbanization and current trends within regional and international context are discussed. The plan making process in Hong Kong including public engagement within the city and the wider GBA context is introduced.

courses.subject: URBD
courses.title: Topical Studies in Urban Design 2 - Urban Transport Networks
courses.description: The course will provide an introduction into history and application of complex urban transportation systems that are globally in use or conception. It will provide introduction to transport concepts, planning aspects, technical requirements and ways of implementation.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of MArch, MSc in Urban Design and MSc in Advanced Environmental Planning Technologies.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Holistic understanding of key infrastructure aspects required for urban design enabling participation in real projects.
Understanding of involvement of stakeholders and various professional disciplines and their roles throughout planning process.
Knowledge of means of communication to various stakeholders realistically participating in similar projects.
Make CUHK a recogniced institution where teaching and discourse on this topic are conducted.
courses.course_syllabus: The course provides an introduction into history and application of complex urban transportation systems that are globally in use or conception. It will provide introduction to transport concepts, planning aspects, technical requirements and ways of implementation.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Course evaluations
Feedback on student papers
External examiners

courses.recommended_readings:

courses.subject: URBD
courses.title: Topical Studies in Urban Design 3 - Urban Management
courses.description: This course provides a base for understanding urban management including the political and socio-economic aspects of urban development, governance issues, planning, policy framework and decision making within a Western and Asian development context. Through a series of lectures and seminars students are introduced to urban management methods and strategies in key areas such as land management, environmental management and public services delivery including associated problems and challenges within the context of Hong Kong and the PRD region.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of MSc in Urban Design.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students begin to appreciate the complex issues, problems and challenges of urban management of development within
a city and regional context.
Students gain an understanding of the methods and strategies used to overcome some of the challenges of urban management. Students learn the importance of collecting data to monitor, evaluate and manage urban development with regards to land, environment and infrastructure etc.
courses.course_syllabus: Through a series of lectures and seminars, students in this course are introduced to urban management by focusing on methods and strategies in key areas such as land management, environmental management and public services delivery in the context of Hong Kong and the Greater Bay Area.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Course evaluations
Feedback on student papers
External examiners
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the recommended readings.
courses.recommended_readings:

Guidelines, Hong Kong: Planning Department.

courses.subject: URBD
courses.title: Topical Studies in Urban Design 4 - International Workshop
courses.description: This course is organized as an intensive workshop and allows students to explore in teams with students and advisors from various international universities a specific issue of urban design. Different international urban conditions are explored through comparative analyses and design. Students can benefit from the exposure to different urban cultures and design approaches. The course also prepares students for a working practice in diverse teams and in different cultural contexts.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of MSc in Urban Design.
courses.learning_outcomes: In an increasingly globalized design practice, the international workshop offers the opportunity to: 1) increase the understanding of different urban conditions and cultures; 2) to learn from different design approaches; 3) to train the working in interdisciplinary and international teams; 4) and, to formulate coherent design and planning concepts in a short period of time.
courses.course_syllabus: This course is organized as an intensive workshop and allows students to explore in teams with students and advisors from various international universities a specific issue of urban design. Different international urban conditions are explored through comparative analyses and design. Students can benefit from the exposure to different urban cultures and design approaches. The course also prepares students for a working practice in diverse teams and in different cultural contexts.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course evaluations, sequence of reviews with invited critics from academia and practice, external examiner report.
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the recommended readings.
courses.recommended_readings: Literature will be selected according to the specific theme and place of the international workshop.

courses.subject: URBD
courses.title: Environmental Design for Liveable and Healthy Cities
courses.description: This course introduces the principles of environmental design in order to maximise the comfort of occupants and minimise the environmental impacts due to the design of building, landscape and urban spaces. The effect of different environmental factors on the built environment is discussed in detail. Design features, such as building’s orientation and form, are closely related to the design details of other design features. The quantitative aspects of the interactions between various design details are discussed with practical examples demonstrating such effects. It also examines the applications of climate-sensitive and environmental urban design in enhancing the living quality as well as the health and well-being of citizens.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc in Urban Design and Master of Architecture
courses.learning_outcomes: Students are expected to attain the knowledge about how climate-sensitive and environmental design creates sustainable neighbourhoods and buildings. They should also be able to: (1) understand the principles of environmental design; (2) explain how urban design features affect environmental conditions; (3) perform numerical modelling (such as geographical information system) for evaluating the environmental performance of urban design; and (4) understand the practical applications in climate-sensitive and environmental urban design and implications on urban living and the health and well-being of citizens.
courses.course_syllabus: Please refer to the course outline.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course evaluations, individual feedback on papers, external examiner report
courses.required_readings: Givoni B, 1998. Climate Considerations in Building and Urban Design. John Wiley & Sons, New York.
courses.recommended_readings:
Landsberg HE, 1981. The Urban Climate. Academic Press, New York.
Oke TR, 2015. Boundary-layer Climates (2nd Edition). Routledge, United Kingdom.
Santamouris M, 2001. Energy and Climate in the Urban Built Environment. Routledge, United Kingdom.

courses.subject: URBD
courses.title: Urban Design Thesis

meetings.instructor:
Professor CHAN Man Ha, 
Professor Jeroen Bastiaan VAN AMEIJDE

Professor CHAN Man Ha, 
Professor Jeroen Bastiaan VAN AMEIJDE

Professor CHAN Man Ha, 
Professor Jeroen Bastiaan VAN AMEIJDE

courses.description: This course covers the general procedures of theoretical inquiry as it relates to urban design, from scoping the research terrain, identifying and focusing on conceptual frameworks and research questions, to determining the techniques, scope and phasing of investigations, as well as criteria for the development of interpretations and paradigms. For the dissertation, students will develop a proposal and produce intellectually rigorous piece of written or designed work. The topic will be defined in discussion with advisors, either in relationship with the design studio, or as an independent research on a topic related to urban design.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students of MSc in Urban Design.
Prerequisite: URBD5720 Urban Design Studio II
courses.learning_outcomes:
The main objective of the thesis work is to provide an opportunity for the student to conduct an independent research and/or design proposal related to a specific interest in the field of Urban Design. The student shall learn to formulate research and/or design problem, define researchable questions and develop solutions for the defined problems.
Students will implement their knowledge on an advanced level and demonstrate an in depth capacity to address challenges stemming from the complex ways in which cities function, grow and develop. The students will gain the professional and theoretical tools to conduct an in depth research as well as to implement their skills and knowledge through the process of design or a written report.
courses.course_syllabus: This course covers the general procedures of theoretical inquiry as it relates to urban design, from scoping the research terrain, identifying and focusing on conceptual frameworks and research questions, to determining the techniques, scope and phasing of investigations, as well as criteria for the development of interpretations and paradigms. For the dissertation, students will develop a proposal and produce intellectually rigorous piece of written or designed work. The topic will be defined in discussion with advisors, either in relationship with the design studio, or as an independent research on a topic related to urban design.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course evaluation, sequence of reviews, external examiner report.
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the recommended readings.
courses.recommended_readings: Literature will depend on individual topics.
